awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Mechanism of Cytochrome P450 Alkene Biosynthesis
awd_abstract_narration:
CAREER: Mechanism of Cytochrome P450 Alkene Biosynthesis

With this CAREER award, the Chemistry of Life Processes in the Chemistry Division of NSF is funding Dr. Thomas Makris from the University of South Carolina to study the mechanism of OleT, a recently discovered enzyme that is involved in the synthesis of hydrocarbons.  The biocatalytic production of hydrocarbons provides a potential route to sustainably produce fuels that are compatible within the existing energy infrastructure.  The atypical reaction catalyzed by OleT consumes hydrogen peroxide, a toxic reactive oxygen species, and transforms biologically abundant fatty acids into alkenes without any additional input of energy.  The goal of this research is to understand both the chemistry of this reaction, and the molecular details which promote it.  Additional broader impacts of this research are in its active involvement of undergraduate and high school students, and the community at large, in an ongoing protein engineering initiative that introduces this hydrocarbon producing capacity into a related enzyme.  The award also supports research for undergraduates from the home institution, and abroad, through a collaborative exchange with a liberal arts college for women, and provides the first research opportunities to high-school students from underrepresented minorities.

The cytochromes P450 are a ubiquitously expressed superfamily of thiolate-ligated heme enzymes that catalyze a diverse set of physiologically important chemical reactions.  Cytochrome P450 enzymes typically insert oxygen atoms into organic substrates using a ferryl intermediate known as Compound I.  OleT forms Compound I, but instead catalyzes a fundamentally different reaction that does not involve oxygen insertion.  The origins for this unusual metal-oxo reprogramming are being probed by biochemical, kinetics, spectroscopic and structural methods.  These methodologies evaluate the individual contributions of electronic structure, secondary coordination sphere, and substrate positioning on promoting the carbon-carbon scission reaction.  Dr. Makris has devised an innovative educational plan, termed Fats to Fuels, that is well integrated into the proposed studies of OleT.  In this plan, undergraduate students and the local community are engaged in learning how fats can be converted to hydrocarbon fuel sources. This research has the potential to impact society with respect to developing new hydrocarbon sources as alternatives to fossil fuels.

por.por_cntn:
PROJECT OUTCOMES REPORT

CAREER: Mechanism of Cytochrome P450 Alkene Biosynthesis (CHE1555066) 

 

Intellectual Merit

This NSF grant aimed to understand the mechanism of a newly discovered enzyme termed OleT. At the inception of this grant, it was recognized that OleT, a member of the cytochrome P450 (CYP) superfamily, was involved in the decarboxylation of fatty acid substrates using hydrogen peroxide as a terminal product. The major product of the reaction, a terminal alkene one carbon shorter than the parent substrate, serves as an advanced “drop-in” biofuel as well as a commodity chemical. From a mechanistic perspective, OleT differs from other CYPs which typically insert oxygen into substrates in what is termed a monooxygenation reaction. Our work on this grant has focused on understanding how OleT differs from other CYPs in its ability to decarboxylate fatty acids (i.e. perform carbon-carbon cleavage rather than monooxygenation. Through identification of the one carbon coproduct (carbon dioxide, CO2) and the use of rapid kinetics measurements, we showed that C-C scission proceeded via a very similar heme-iron intermediate (an Fe4+-OH species) as that shown for monooxygenation and through a very similar process (hydrogen atom transfer). However, the next steps profoundly differ in that OleT does not perform oxygen rebound. Thus, a key mechanistic question that arose from these early studies was the role of the protein active-site  in promoting alkene formation. The role of the protein and substrate structure on steering OleT towards monooxygenation was probed in a variety of ways. Using substrate analogs, we established that substrate-type (e.g. fatty acid chain length) was critical for reinforcing this chemistry. This interplay was further established through alteration of the protein structure, as introduced alterations at sites quite distant from the site of chemistry radically altered the chemical outcome. Finally, structure/function correlations were further established through the study of various orthologs of OleT (i.e. proteins of similar sequence/structure, but with varying propensities for C-C cleavage versus monooxygenation). Taken together, the studies of OleT have shown how heme-iron enzymes can catalyze very different reactions through (a) controlling the reactivity of specific oxidizing species, and (b) binding substrates in a defined manner. These outcomes have significant relevance both for leveraging OleT for hydrocarbon synthesis and for the development of synthetic processes that aim to mimic its biochemistry.

 

Broader Impacts

The broader impacts of this grant have been in the training of STEM students at various levels of their educations (from high-school to (post)graduate) in an ongoing protein engineering project, using OleT as a scaffold for study. Tangible outcomes have included the active involvement of over 20 undergraduates and 3 high school students that received their first opportunities in inquiry-based research in the laboratory. Training within the laboratory has involved a diverse group of students and a significant number of historical minorities in the STEM workforce. At the graduate level, six students that received partial support from this project successfully defended their PhD dissertations and have gone on to successful careers in various sectors of government, industry, and academia.  One additional student from the NSF funded Interdisciplinary Biochemistry Master’s program (IBMP) received a master’s degree and transitioned to a career in biotechnology. In addition to training students within the laboratory, the project has also involved a broader community of trainees. An undergraduate biochemistry laboratory course was completely redeveloped using OleT as a scaffold of study. Students were introduced to concepts in (a) protein structure and design, (b) heterologous protein overproduction and purification, and (c) protein characterization. The laboratory established an inquiry-based approach to develop variants of OleT that improved/impaired activity. Results were then rationalized based on anticipated structural changes of the protein through analysis of crystallographic data.

 


Last Modified: 02/14/2024
Modified by: Thomas Makris

PROJECT OUTCOMES REPORT 


CAREER: Mechanism of Cytochrome P450 Alkene Biosynthesis (CHE1555066)





Intellectual Merit
